Panel Name

fwElmbCANSystemViewOperation.pnl
Introduction
 This panel is used for the operation of the CAN buses that have been created in the current system.
Instructions There are two main 'sections' to this panel (Figure 1):

Table Showing Information

There are a number of columns shown in this table. Below is a brief description of what information is shown in each column, and when available, what operations are possible.

Bus Name - This displays the name of the CAN bus as given at creation time

Elmb Count - This displays the number of ELMBs that are currently defined on this CANbus

Interface - The CAN interface card type is displayed here.

Port - The port that is being used on the repective CAN interface card is displayed.

Speed - The bus speed (or baud rate) is displayed in this column. This value can be changed by clicking on this column for the CANbus that you wish to alter the bus speed for. A panel is displayed allowing you to alter this value.

Sync. Int. - This displays the SYNC interval (the time period between successive SYNC messages being sent to the CANbus). This value can be changed by clicking on this column for the required CANbus. A panel is displayed allowing you to then alter this value.

Guard Int - This displays the Node Guard Interval (the time period between successive Node Guard messages being sent to the CANbus). Clicking on this column for the required CANbus displays a panel that allows you to alter the value.

Port Error - This displays the value of the port error. If this value is zero, there is no error on the CANbus. If this value is NOT zero, an error has been found on the CANbus. You may need to refer to the documentation for the relevant CAN interface card to discover the meaning of this error code.

Send message to CANbus

Three operations are available from this section. You must select a CANbus from the table (by clicking on the column 'Bus Name' for the required bus, or any other column that does not have an action associated with it) before you can send a message to the CANbus.

Start - Clicking this button sends an NMT (Network ManagemenT) command to the selected CANbus that starts (or sets operational) all ELMBs on that bus.

Stop - Clicking this button sends an NMT Stop command to all ELMBs on the selected CANbus.

Reset - Clicking this button sends an NMT Reset command to all ELMBs on the selected CANbus. This will cause the ELMBs to re-boot, and therefore a bootup message should be seen from each node.
